Award.AwardTitle: Training workshop on genomic methods and analysis for early-career invertebrate systematists
Award.AbstractNarration:
Invertebrates represent 95% of animal diversity, yet few genomic resources exist for the group, leaving a great deal of information on gene diversity and function to be discovered. Coordination among limited research efforts is lacking, limiting comparability among projects and in some cases resulting in duplicated efforts. The Global Invertebrate Genomics Alliance (GIGA) is a network of diverse scientists working to coordinate and advance invertebrate research using advanced techniques to shed light on this genomic diversity and guide scientific discoveries. This workshop, hosted at the 3rd bi-annual GlGA Conference, will provide a much-needed training opportunity for graduate students and early-career researchears in the latest cutting-edge approaches for comparative genomics and bioinformatics in systematic biology. The workshop will also get participants actively involved with developing best practices in invertebrate genomics. Workshop participants will be recruited from diverse levels of expertise with a specific effort to target underrepresented minorities. Information from this workshop will be shared with students and the community at large through publicly available learning exercises and tutorials, facilitating information access to minority groups. Material from this workshop will also be showcased through several media outlets to emphasize the link and importance of invertebrate animals to society as well as the power of genomics in studying marine resources and habitats.

The few invertebrate genomes that have been fully sequenced reveal major structural differences with vertebrates, unusual frequencies of transposable elements and genomic innovations among other features. Presently, research coordination among scientists carrying out non-model invertebrate genomics research remains sparse or scattered. Additionally, as a whole, the invertebrate systematics community is inadequately trained to work broadly at the genomic level, thus hampering progress elucidating the evolutionary history for most of the life on earth. This workshop will work to position invertebrate systematists at the leading edge of phylogenomics methodology and begin the process of catching up to their vertebrate systematics counterparts. Primary objectives of this workshop are to 1) provide bioinformatics training and support to the community; 2) promote the sharing of data, resources, and future collaborations; 3) disseminate knowledge on the best practices for laboratory protocols and techniques; and 4) inform and support student researchers in the field of invertebrate genomics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal funded fellowships for graduate and early-career postdoctoral students from 14 U.S. based institutions to attend the 3rd Global Invertebrate Genomics Alliance (GIGA) meeting in Cura?ao in October 2018. Instead of our anticipated 16 awards, we were able to fund fellowships for 18 meritorious graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Awardees were selected for these fellowships by members of the GIGA Steering Committee based on a statement of financial need and the quality of an essay describing their research projects. Under-represented groups were solicited for these awards, with 14 of the 18 fellowships awarded to women in STEM programs. The fellowships helped cover round-trip travel to the conference location from their US-based institutions and/or lodging for the duration of the meeting. Student attendance at previous GIGA conferences was restricted due to limited funding from respective grants and institutions. These fellowships therefore provided student researchers in the field of invertebrate genomics and systematics an invaluable opportunity to receive training and support along-side experts in their field. In addition to attendance, this award supported female postdoctoral STEM researchers to lead workshop components and give keynote addresses.

 

The conference award allowed students to present their research findings at the meeting and gain critical feedback from the scientific community. It also enabled the training of students and researchers in genomics and bioinformatic techniques. Researchers learned cutting-edge techniques towards the assembly and annotation of existing high-throughput sequencing data. Participants were also introduced to a series of standardized sampling protocols and practices for more replicable and comparable results, while optimizing limited resources. Students and early-career researchers also received guidance and support for their research projects in the field of invertebrate genomics and systematics.

 

Active-learning and bioinformatic modules were also generated during the conference and associated workshops, which are publicly available through GIGA's website. Students and researchers also gained insight and skills during the workshops that will be incorporated into research projects and training at their respective institutions. Some testimonials from fellowship recipients are provided below, to emphasize the importance of this funding and the impact it made on the young scientists who were able to attend because of it:

 

"The GIGA conference in Curacao allowed invertebrate researchers from all over the world to strengthen a network for answering the numerous unknowns related to the realm of invertebrate genomics..... I really enjoyed the workshops on various genomics techniques because while there are tutorials online, having folks who study similar organisms share their experience while going through the steps is very beneficial....Without this NSF travel support, I would not have been able to attend, and I would not have been able to collect samples for a portion of dissertation relating to microbiome's of coral reefs. I was able to present my research thus far and gain valuable feedback on how to improve my analyses before my next steps. I am so very grateful for the opportunity to attend, so thank you very much!"

 

"I truly enjoyed the GIGA III meeting. This is the first time I have attend a genomics meeting, which is one of the main tools I would like to explore and add to my toolbox during my postdoc. Since I am just started my postdoctoral fellowship, I had no funding to afford traveling to the GIGA III meeting, and therefore defray the costs of airfare and lodging. The NSF travel grant awarded not only provided me with the necessary funds to offset the cost of attending the meeting, but was pivotal for advancing my career goals, allowing me to interact and network with key researchers in the field of genomics, and to learn about some cutting-edge work on invertebrate genomics."

 

"This funding allowed me to attend the GIGA conference and I am so grateful.  The workshops taught me useful knowledge that I will need to analyze my data to complete my graduate thesis for, and the presentations taught me about organisms I knew very little about.  Overall, the conference was a great learning experience and the funding allowed me to enjoy the trip even more."

 

"I was able to attend the Global Invertebrate Genomic Alliance (GIGA) Meeting in Curacao because of the grant offered by NSF. If I did not have support for housing during the meeting, I would not have been able to go and present two chapters of my thesis research. Graduate students generally do not have the resources to pay for a four night hotel stay at a hotel where a conference is being held especially because those places tend to be in central places.... Without the help to pay for housing from NSF, I would not have been able to attend the conference where I got exposure for my work and extremely valuable advice on how to improve my thesis work."
